jacques-n commented on issue #5526: [ARROW-6723][Java] Reduce the range of synchronized block when releasing an ArrowBuf
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5526#issuecomment-536089694
 
 
   We spent months working through the locking model of the allocator. It is very complex (I worked a lot on it). I am not confident this is a safe change. I also question the importance of this change. Retain/release should be called several orders of magnitude less often than interaction with individual cell values. It is also atypical for a large number of threads to be acting on the same buffer releasing and retaining at the same time (which would be required to have true contention). Do you have a workload where this actually causing a major impact on end to end performance?

liyafan82 commented on issue #5526: [ARROW-6723][Java] Reduce the range of synchronized block when releasing an ArrowBuf
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5526#issuecomment-536241069
 
 
   > We spent months working through the locking model of the allocator. It is very complex (I worked a lot on it). I am not confident this is a safe change. I also question the importance of this change. Retain/release should be called several orders of magnitude less often than interaction with individual cell values. It is also atypical for a large number of threads to be acting on the same buffer releasing and retaining at the same time (which would be required to have true contention). Do you have a workload where this actually causing a major impact on end to end performance?
   
   @jacques-n Thanks a lot for your valueable comments.
   I understand that the locking model is complex and difficult to reasoning about, so we should be extremely careful about the change.
   I agree that the number of calls is much smaller than the calls for cell APIs.
   
   I scenario is that in a distributed task, it allocates a large number of ArrowBufs. For example, for a hash join task, it has a number of partitions for the hash table. For each partition, it allocates various buffers/vectors for the bucket area, record area, probe buffer, etc. All such buffers are allocated from the same allocator, so they share the same allocation manager may cause contention when closed simultaneously. 
   
   In our scenario, there can be about 80 threads/tasks sharing the same JVM (I know this is not a typical way of sharing resources, but it is actually used in some systems, e.g. Apache Flink). Most of them can be closed at almost the same time. So the resouce contention can be insignificant.
   
   It is difficult to evaluate the effect of this problem in isolation for an online job. I will try to provide an evaluation by simulation.

jacques-n commented on issue #5526: ARROW-6723: [Java] Reduce the range of synchronized block when releasing an ArrowBuf
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5526#issuecomment-536395172
 
 
   I think you're confused about the allocation manager, there is one per allocation, not per allocator. In order to hit contention you would need to have many threads releasing the same memory allocation at the same time. Even then, the serialization of threads lasts for a single atomic cas for all but one of those threads. It feels like a made up problem to me. If you change this block, do you have real world numbers that show a substantial change in performance. Anything you are worried about here seems like it would be microscopic to even a simple hash table construction.

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5526#issuecomment-536466596
 
 
   > I think you're confused about the allocation manager, there is one per allocation, not per allocator. In order to hit contention you would need to have many threads releasing the same memory allocation at the same time. Even then, the serialization of threads lasts for a single atomic cas for all but one of those threads. It feels like a made up problem to me. If you change this block, do you have real world numbers that show a substantial change in performance. Anything you are worried about here seems like it would be microscopic to even a simple hash table construction.
   
   Thanks a lot for your clarification and sorry about my confusion.
   After examining the code, I find different buffers actually have separate allocation managers, so there is no resource contention. 
   
   I have also prepared a simple benchmark to evaluate the scenario when multiple threads try to close a large number of buffers. The results show no significant difference (as expected):
   
   before
   3839.636 ±(99.9%) 1365.557 us/op [Average]
     (min, avg, max) = (3542.942, 3839.636, 4349.512), stdev = 354.631
     CI (99.9%): [2474.079, 5205.193] (assumes normal distribution)
   
   after
   3797.679 ±(99.9%) 358.644 us/op [Average]
     (min, avg, max) = (3697.749, 3797.679, 3917.188), stdev = 93.139
     CI (99.9%): [3439.035, 4156.324] (assumes normal distribution)
   
   Given the potential unsafety of this change, I don't think it should be merged. 
   So I will keep it for a few days, and if no one has any more comments, I will close it.

comments.body:
This change is not guaranteed to be safe. 
In addition, different ArrowBuf have separate allocation manangers, so it does not lead to resource contention for most scenarios.
